timeline.bodyText: I am not sure that stream usage is justified here. It generates the boxed sequence, sorts it if needed, allocates additional unnecessary objects, etc. As an idea, can't we just have two int fields, e.g. from and to that we set depending on the reverse flag, also probably we need the sign, so we know whether we inc or dec or smth similar? Something like that will be definitely more efficient than the current stream API usage.
timeline.author: kovrus

timeline.bodyText: The same comment about the stream API usage. It is probably not that necessary to create a new stream object to iterate over a list and do some predicate checks. You can achieve that with the for-loop in a not less concise manner as well.
timeline.author: kovrus

timeline.bodyText: Same here, see the previous comments.
timeline.author: kovrus

timeline.bodyText: can we add tests that cover both scenarios?
timeline.author: kovrus

timeline.bodyText: maybe align this variable. not sure why we need another static field for it.
timeline.author: kovrus

timeline.bodyText: it is a bit confusing, array becomes nested?
timeline.author: kovrus

timeline.bodyText: not really related, but i am wondering whether assertions like these still make sense. isn't it already guarded by the func resolving/registration logic?
timeline.author: kovrus

replies.bodyText:
It is guarded by the function signature, but using assertions like this can be a useful defensive programming technique.
It makes explicit that there exists some contract. It can help debugging in case the other component no longer ensures this.
But the assertion message could be improved.

  
    
  
    

  
  This file contains bidirectional Unicode text that may be interpreted or compiled differently than what appears below. To review, open the file in an editor that reveals hidden Unicode characters. Learn more about bidirectional Unicode characters


  


    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
                    assert args.length == 2 || args.length == 3 : "number of args must be 2 or 3";
          
          
            
                    assert args.length == 2 || args.length == 3 : "Signature must ensure that there are either two or three arguments";
replies.author: mfussenegger

timeline.bodyText: Could move this check above the previous check, then the oi != null check could be removed as it becomes redundant.
timeline.author: mfussenegger

timeline.bodyText: I think the name doesn't really fit. It implies that it verifies some condition, but also has a return value without indicating what the value is about.
timeline.author: mfussenegger
mfussenegger

timeline.bodyText: dim == null case needs to be handled as well. This causes a NullPointerException as it is.
timeline.author: mfussenegger
mfussenegger

timeline.bodyText: This raises a NullPointerException if the reversed flag argument is null
timeline.author: mfussenegger

timeline.bodyText: What do you think about extracting parts of the evaluate of generate_series and re-using it here?
timeline.author: mfussenegger

timeline.bodyText: Is subscripts the right field-name?
timeline.author: mfussenegger

timeline.message:
Change the name of the column, because see below:

postgres=# select * from generate_subscripts('{1}'::int[], 1);
 generate_subscripts
---------------------
                   1
(1 row)
Two functions that belong to the pg_catalog

timeline.bodyText: Why the change to Bucket? This can still be an Iterable, the additional size info of Bucket is not required or used.
timeline.author: mfussenegger

timeline.bodyText:
I think the U extends Number constraint is unecessary, no?
Also not sure about the name. I think it emphases the SingleColumn part too much. How about just RangeIterator, SeriesGenerator, or GenerateSeriesIterator ?
Also, could this an Iterable? Would make it a bit more powerful
timeline.author: mfussenegger

timeline.author: kovrus

timeline.message:
Add table function generate_subscripts

Convenience function that generates the set of valid subscripts for the
specified dimension of the given array. Zero rows are returned for arrays
that do not have the requested dimension, or for NULL arrays (but valid
subscripts are returned for NULL array elements).

Add table function generate_subscripts

Convenience function that generates the set of valid subscripts for the
specified dimension of the given array. Zero rows are returned for arrays
that do not have the requested dimension, or for NULL arrays (but valid
subscripts are returned for NULL array elements).
